Unexpected ownership transfer within a get_property call

note.body:
I have multiple `webrtcbins` that I need to create and remove dynamically. Which of those would be a better workaround?

**Option 1**, manually increasing the refcount of the object and leaving it hanging forever
```
ice_agent:Gst.Element = webrtcbin.get_property('ice-agent')
ice_agent.get_property('agent').connect("new-selected-pair-full", self.on_new_selected_pair)
py_object = ctypes.py_object(ice_agent)
ctypes.pythonapi.Py_IncRef(py_object)
```
The idea is that then Gstreamer can do whatever it wants to the object and we don't have to keep references to all the ice-agents in the application. The downside is the possible memory leak, because we can never garbage collect the ice_agent objects.

**Option 2** 
```
peer_id = "123" # some uuid
ice_agent:Gst.Element = webrtcbin.get_property('ice-agent')
ice_agent.get_property('agent').connect("new-selected-pair-full", self.on_new_selected_pair)
self.webrtc_handler.ice_agents[peer_id] = ice_agent
...
del self.webrtc_handler.ice_agents[peer_id]
```
This should avoid the memory leak, however Gstreamer (GObject?) throws this error:
```
(python3:39): GStreamer-CRITICAL **: 13:37:36.908: gst_object_unref: assertion '((GObject *) object)->ref_count > 0' failed
```
Now this doesn't crash the pipeline and everything seems to work as expected, but this error makes me think that manipulating memory like this isn't preferred and may lead to larger issues down the road. Is my assumption correct or can I safely ignore this error in this case?

note.body:
I'm not sure there is a clean way to solve this. Here is the code that initialises GObject instances:

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/55fbcb21d9183f7d70582df373ed46a73737d7be/gobject/gtype.c#L1937-1951

Of note, the instance's g_class pointer is set to the superclass while each superclass `instance_init` function is run. So when that logging callback is made, the instance really is a `GstBin`.

I'm not sure how you'd fix this while keeping a one-to-one mapping between the C objects and Python wrappers.

I've created !387 that might be worth merging before doing this C code reformatting. There's a few places clang-format makes some bad decisions, and some small code modifications improve things noticeably.

There's a few changes to improve formatting of break statements where a case has been wrapped in a block. I also updated the config to give hints about the `_PyGI_ENUM_*` macros so the enum definitions in `pygi-info.c` don't get mangled.

note.body:
I don't think there is a clean way to fix this: if glib fixes the reference imbalance (either as https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/merge_requests/4415 tried to, or by now switching the `g_dbus_method_invocation_return_*` functions to use `transfer none`), then old versions of pygobject will trigger a reference underrun.

New versions of pygobject could check the glib version (or perhaps inspect the typeinfo for one of the `return_*` functions) and only do the unref with old versions of glib. There'd still be a problem for e.g. people pulling a pinned version of pygobject from pypi and using it with a fixed glib version.

target_title: anaconda (Fedora / RHEL installer) frequently crashes on exit with pygobject 3.50.0 (bisected)

note.body:
The manual unref in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pygobject/-/commit/bf80d0f34af5062fd1201d71fbcd3a34bf1d1a80 still smells a bit.

I think the unbalanced ref count comes from the `g_dbus_method_invocation_return_*` functions setting `transfer full` for the invocation:

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/7ac156401dd23f994e0b75abda9fb40f98aa64a3/gio/gdbusmethodinvocation.c#L537

So when pygobject calls those functions, it will first increment the reference count on the invocation.

If the intent is that there is a magic reference that will be consumed by one of the `return_*` functions, then those functions should be `transfer none`. While they might consume a reference to the invocation, they're not consuming the _caller's_ reference.

Annoyingly, changing to `transfer none` would instead create a reference underflow when `wrapped_method_call_closure` calls unref.

Passing -128 to GtkApplication.add_main_object’s option parameter causes SystemError

note.body:
Playing around with this, I can reproduce as follows:

```python-repl
>>> app.add_main_option("foo", -128, 0, arg, "", "")
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0x80 in position 61: invalid start byte

The above exception was the direct cause of the following exception:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
SystemError: gi.FunctionInfo(add_main_option, bound=<Gio.Application object at 0x79d642f0f700 (GApplication at 0x1b00dd0)>) returned a result with an exception set
```

At the C level the argument in question is supposed to be a character, so in that sense a value of -128 doesn't really make sense. We end up with a different error passing a single character string, and maybe that should be treated as a bug:

```python-repl
>>> app.add_main_option("foo", "f", 0, arg, "", "")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: Must be number, not str
```

If you used a fuzzing tool to find this bug, it'd be good to state that upfront about that we know the combination of arguments might not make sense.

It looks like this broke the exit handler of anaconda (the Fedora / RHEL installer). With this override applied, it frequently crashes, meaning the installer doesn't shut down properly, and doesn't poweroff or reboot the system if that's what you asked it to do. The crash looks like this:
```
DEBUG:anaconda.modules.boss.module_manager.module_manager:Stop modules.
DEBUG:dasbus.connection:Disconnecting from the bus.
DEBUG:anaconda.modules.boss.module_manager.module_manager:org.fedoraproject.Anaconda.Modules.Services has quit.
DEBUG:dasbus.connection:Disconnecting from the bus.
WARNING:dasbus.server.handler:The call org.fedoraproject.Anaconda.Boss.Quit has failed with an exception:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/dasbus/server/handler.py", line 455, in _method_callback
    result = self._handle_call(
        interface_name,
    ...<2 lines>...
        **additional_args
    )
  File "/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/dasbus/server/handler.py", line 265, in _handle_call
    return handler(*parameters, **additional_args)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.13/site-packages/pyanaconda/modules/boss/boss_interface.py", line 155, in Quit
    self.implementation.stop()
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.13/site-packages/pyanaconda/modules/boss/boss.py", line 76, in stop
    self._module_manager.stop_modules()
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.13/site-packages/pyanaconda/modules/boss/module_manager/module_manager.py", line 94, in stop_modules
    observer.proxy.Quit()
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^
  File "/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/dasbus/client/handler.py", line 450, in _call_method
    return self._get_method_reply(
           ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^
        self._client.sync_call,
        ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
        *args,
        ^^^^^^
        **kwargs,
        ^^^^^^^^^
    )
    ^
  File "/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/dasbus/client/handler.py", line 483, in _get_method_reply
    return self._handle_method_error(error)
           ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/dasbus/client/handler.py", line 509, in _handle_method_error
    raise exception from None
dasbus.error.DBusError: Message recipient disconnected from message bus without replying
```

Not sure if this change was inherently a bad idea, or it's exposing something bad in anaconda's dbus usage/teardown. See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2329587 .

target_title: Warning "expected enumeration type void, but got PyGLibOptionArg instead"

note.body:
The common thread between this issue and #639 are enumeration types that are not registered with the GLib type system by their respective libraries. Note the missing `glib:get-type` attributes:

```xml
<enumeration name="OptionArg" c:type="GOptionArg">
<enumeration name="RepoCheckoutMode" c:type="OstreeRepoCheckoutMode">
```

In this case, the code in `gi/module.py` will register a GType itself with the `Py` prefix:

```python
                        if g_type.is_a(TYPE_ENUM):
                            wrapper = enum_add(g_type)
                        else:
                            assert g_type == TYPE_NONE
                            wrapper = enum_register_new_gtype_and_add(info)
```

The "void" in the warning is the name of `G_TYPE_NONE`. Perhaps the best fix would be to skip the warning in `pyg_enum_get_value` if `enum_type == G_TYPE_NONE`.

target_title: Warning "expected enumeration type void, but got PyOSTreeRepoCheckoutMode instead"

note.body:
The warning is printing the mismatched C-level `GType` values. We can see the `PyOSTreeRepoCheckoutMode` name here:

```
>>> from gi.repository import OSTree
<stdin>:1: PyGIWarning: OSTree was imported without specifying a version first. Use gi.require_version('OSTree', '1.0') before import to ensure that the right version gets loaded.
>>> OSTree.RepoCheckoutMode.__gtype__
<GType PyOSTreeRepoCheckoutMode (370499584)>
```

This seems to indicate it was created by this code path when we don't know the GType for the enumeration:

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pygobject/-/blob/main/gi/module.py#L150-152

And looking at the GIR for OSTree, there is no `glib:get-type` attribute on the enumeration:

```xml
   <enumeration name="RepoCheckoutMode" c:type="OstreeRepoCheckoutMode">
```

I agree that this looks like a dupe of #608, since `GOptionArg` is also missing a GType.

target_title: gi: add option to skip automatic init of Gdk and Gtk on import

note.body:
@amolenaar 
> I don't think that's a problem. If you want the (auto) init disabled, you want it for a reason. So you'll need to set a miminum version of PyGObject.

I personally disagree with that. @g.willems's concern is, IMHO, valid. Please don't make it harder to support versions of PyGObject that users _actually_ have installed on their systems.

Something like `Gtk.disable_setlocale()` is a good example, because it's functionality that isn't remotely important enough to render some code **completely incompatible** with all previous PyGObject versions.

As an application developer, I'm fine to say, "If you're using PyGObject version N.M or later, we can disable Gtk's automatic `set_locale` and set the Gtk locale. With any earlier versions, that won't work so it'll be set to whatever the user locale is."

I'd certainly vastly prefer that to, "This code requires PyGObject version N.M or later, because we expect to have access to functionality that 99% of users don't need anyway."

So, it'd be nice if adding support for calling `Gtk.disable_setlocale()` could be added to a codebase could involve minimal hoops to jump through, in order to retain backwards-compatibility.

(I'm assuming that if autoinit _isn't_ disabled, `Gtk.disable_setlocale()` can still be called, but it will simply have no effect because it's too late? If that's the case, then yes, using a variable would make life much easier, because the application code could simply be:

```python
import gi
gi.disable_legacy_autoinit = True  # Only works in pygobject-N.M+
gi.require_version('Gtk', '4.0')
from gi.repository import Gtk
Gtk.disable_setlocale()  # Only effective if disable_legacy_autoinit supported
```

As opposed to,
```python
import gi
if hasattr(gi.disable_legacy_autoinit):
    gi.disable_legacy_autoinit()
gi.require_version('Gtk', '4.0')
from gi.repository import Gtk
Gtk.disable_setlocale()  # Only effective if disable_legacy_autoinit supported
```

Or (worse!)
```python
import gi
gi.check_version("N.M")  # Will raise a ValueError with older versions
gi.disable_legacy_autoinit()
gi.require_version('Gtk', '4.0')
from gi.repository import Gtk
Gtk.disable_setlocale()
```

Developers can always include the version check, if they _want_ to require support for `disable_legacy_autoinit`. But it's a bad assumption, to say that _supporting_ it equates to _requiring_ it.

target_title: gi: add option to skip automatic init of Gdk and Gtk on import

note.body:
I personally like to have "legacy" in the name to point out that's it's an unnecessary hack only kept for backwards compatibility reasons and planned to be removed in the future.

`disable_gtk_autoinit` seems too restrictive because Gdk is involved too (at least Gdk3). And I don't wanted to be too specific by naming modules.

I updated the code to use a function instead of a public dictionary. I used my proposed name for now, but we may change it later. I'm still a bit concerned with that solution, because users will have to do something like:
```python
if hasattr(gi, 'disable_legacy_autoinit'):
    gi.disable_legacy_autoinit()
```
to support old pygobject versions...

Would it be acceptable to use a simple variable?
```python
gi.disable_legacy_autoinit = True
```
The big advantage is that there will be no need to use `hasattr` or any version check, doing that on old pygobject versions will be harmless and simply ignored.

note.body:
But... that wasn't done. :grinning: The constructor override only accepts numeric values. It _could_ accept strings as well, easily:

```python
class RGBA(Gdk.RGBA):
    def __init__(self, red=1.0, green=1.0, blue=1.0, alpha=1.0):
        Gdk.RGBA.__init__(self)
        if isinstance(red, str):
            self.parse(red)
        else:
            self.red = red
            self.green = green
            self.blue = blue
            self.alpha = alpha
```

That'd allow calling any of `Gdk.RGBA(1, 0, 0, 1)` or `Gdk.RGBA(1, 0, 0)` or `Gdk.RGBA("#ff0000")` to accomplish the same thing.

note.body:
Following on from @creiter's !362 about adjusting the minimum Python version to try and exclude systems without libgirepository-2.0, I had a play with the bigquery pypi stats as described [here](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/guides/analyzing-pypi-package-downloads/).

Using the following query:

```sql
SELECT
  COUNT(*) as num_downloads,
  details.distro.name AS distro_name,
  details.distro.version AS distro_version,
  REGEXP_EXTRACT(details.python, r"[0-9]+\.[0-9]+") AS python_version
FROM `bigquery-public-data.pypi.file_downloads`
WHERE
  file.project = 'pygobject' AND
  DATE(timestamp) BETWEEN DATE_SUB(CURRENT_DATE(), INTERVAL 1 month) AND CURRENT_DATE()
GROUP BY distro_name, distro_version, python_version
ORDER BY num_downloads DESC;
```

Shows quite a spread users, including multiple Python versions on various distro releases, and many using currently unsupported Python releases:

| num_downloads | distro_name | distro_version | python_version |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| 499155 | Ubuntu | 18.04 | 3.6 |
| 53539 | Ubuntu | 24.04 | 3.12 |
| 40669 | Ubuntu | 22.04 | 3.10 |
| 36855 | Debian GNU/Linux | 12 | 3.11 |
| 30765 |  |  |  |
| 30546 | Debian GNU/Linux | 11 | 3.9 |
| 12097 | Ubuntu | 20.04 | 3.8 |
| 8308 | macOS | 10.16 | 3.7 |
| 6026 | Ubuntu | 18.04 | 3.7 |
| 5758 | Debian GNU/Linux | 12 | 3.12 |
| 5333 | Ubuntu | 22.04 | 3.12 |
| 5219 | Slackware | 14.2 | 2.7 |
| 5189 | Slackware | 14.2 | 3.6 |
| 4666 | Ubuntu | 22.04 | 3.8 |
| 4160 | Debian GNU/Linux | 12 | 3.10 |
| 4040 | Ubuntu | 24.04 | 3.11 |
| 3484 | Debian GNU/Linux | 12 | 3.8 |
| 3471 | Ubuntu | 22.04 | 3.11 |
| 3309 | macOS | 10.15.7 | 3.7 |
| 3145 | Debian GNU/Linux | 12 | 3.7 |
...

I'm kind of curious about the large number of Ubuntu 18.04/Python 3.6 users there.

If we instead look at downloads of the 3.50.0 release over all time (which will exclude people using ancient Python versions or who have pinned old releases), we get:

| num_downloads | distro_name | distro_version | python_version |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| 77371 | Ubuntu | 24.04 | 3.12 |
| 41548 | Ubuntu | 22.04 | 3.10 |
| 23242 | Debian GNU/Linux | 12 | 3.11 |
| 21741 | Debian GNU/Linux | 11 | 3.9 |
| 9071 |  |  |  |
| 8333 | Ubuntu | 22.04 | 3.12 |
| 6272 | Debian GNU/Linux | 12 | 3.12 |
| 4020 | Ubuntu | 22.04 | 3.11 |
| 3174 | Ubuntu | 24.04 | 3.11 |
| 2619 |  |  | 3.12 |
| 2608 | Fedora Linux | 40 | 3.12 |
| 2572 | Debian GNU/Linux | 12 | 3.10 |
| 2100 | Ubuntu | 20.04 | 3.9 |
| 2044 | macOS | 14.6.1 | 3.12 |
| 2008 |  |  | 3.11 |
| 1792 | Arch Linux |  | 3.12 |
| 1670 | Linux Mint | 22 | 3.12 |
| 1332 | Ubuntu | 20.04 | 3.11 |
| 1206 | Ubuntu | 20.04 | 3.10 |
| 1033 | Debian GNU/Linux | 12 | 3.9 |
...

Interestingly, there are people using Python 3.12 on old distros like Ubuntu 22.04 and Debian 11. There's also people running distros with new enough glib but old Python releases.

Bumping the minimum Python version to 3.12 would hide the increased glib version requirement for most people, but not all. It would also strand some users on old pygobject versions when they could still use the the current release.

I'm not sure there is a good answer here.

target_title: async: Use correct T_BOOL type for _asyncio_future_blocking

note.body:
> Should we maybe use `Py_T_BOOL` there then?

You could change all uses of `T_BOOL`, `T_OBJECT`, etc. into `Py_T_BOOL`, `Py_T_OBJECT`, etc. as an orthogonal change if you want to reduce namespace pollution and are willing to drop support for Python older than 3.12, but that wouldn't solve the bug.

`T_BOOL`, etc. are analogous to `G_TYPE_BOOLEAN`, etc. and are not C type names, so we can't declare `T_BOOL _asyncio_future_blocking;` in the C struct - we have to "just know" the mapping from the table I linked, where a `PyMemberDef` with type `T_BOOL` (or equivalently `Py_T_BOOL`) must correspond to a C struct member with type `char` and so on.

target_title: TestAsync failing on big-endian machines like s390x: RuntimeError: yield was used instead of yield from

note.body:
I think I might have found the problem. In `gi/pygi-async.c`, `_asyncio_future_blocking` is declared as having type `T_BOOL`, which requires the corresponding struct member `PyGIAsync._asyncio_future_blocking` to have type `char` as per the table in <https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/structures.html#member-types>. But the struct member actually has type `int`.

On big-endian architectures, this means that storing `TRUE` in it will only set the last byte, but Python is looking at only the first byte.

(Conversely, on little-endian, storing `TRUE` in an `int` sets the first byte, and the code works even though it's wrong.)

target_title: TestAsync failing on big-endian machines like s390x: RuntimeError: yield was used instead of yield from

```
tests/test_async.py:98:

/usr/lib64/python3.13/asyncio/base_events.py:721: in run_until_complete

E       RuntimeError: yield was used instead of yield from in task <Task pending name='Task-6' coro=<TestAsync.test_not_completed.<locals>.run() running at /builddir/build/BUILD/pygobject3-3.50.0-build/pygobject-3.50.0/tests/test_async.py:96> cb=[_run_until_complete_cb() at /usr/lib64/python3.13/asyncio/base_events.py:182]> with gi._gi.Async(finish_func=Gio.File.enumerate_children_finish, done=False)
```

Add overrides for GdkRGBA and in particular GdkRGBA.parse()

note.body:
_This_ ugliness "works"...

```python
class RGBA

    # ...

    _parse = Gdk.RGBA.parse

    @classmethod
    def parse(cls, spec):
        color = cls()
        ret = color._parse(spec)
        return color if ret else None
```

**Buuuuut** it still breaks use as an instance method, since `.parse()` now returns a new instance instead of modifying the existing instance like it used to:

```python
>>> import gi; gi.require_version('Gdk', '4.0')
>>> from gi.repository import Gdk
>>> c = Gdk.RGBA.parse("#ff0000")
>>> c
Gdk.RGBA(red=1.000000, green=0.000000, blue=0.000000, alpha=1.000000)
>>> c.parse("#ee0000")
Gdk.RGBA(red=0.933333, green=0.000000, blue=0.000000, alpha=1.000000)
>>> c
Gdk.RGBA(red=1.000000, green=0.000000, blue=0.000000, alpha=1.000000)
>>> # You have to call it as c._parse() now...
>>> c._parse("#00ff00")
True
>>> c
Gdk.RGBA(red=0.000000, green=1.000000, blue=0.000000, alpha=1.000000)
```

target_title: Add overrides for GdkRGBA and in particular GdkRGBA.parse()

note.body:
It wouldn't really matter if the override is a `@staticmethod` or a `@classmethod` — well, the only difference is that as a `@classmethod` it would have access to the class to be instantiated as an argument, whereas the `@staticmethod` would have to hardcode it. But that'd be the only difference:

```python
class RGBA:

    @classmethod
    def parse(cls, spec):
        color = cls()
        ret = color.parse(spec)
        return color if ret else None

    @staticmethod
    def parse(spec):
        color = Gdk.RGBA()
        ret = color.parse(spec)
        return color if ret else None
```

Either could be called as `Gdk.RGBA.parse("#ff0000")` to return a new `Gdk.RGBA` instance containing the parsed color `#ff0000`.

Whichever way it's implemented, though, I don't think it can be called `parse()` without breaking the class; is there a way to call the instance method `color.parse()` after `parse()` has been redefined as a class/staticmethod? Neither of the above definitions will actually work, because the `ret = color.parse(spec)` line becomes either infinite recursion (classmethod), or a call with too many arguments (staticmethod).

I'd think the override would have to be named something else, like `color_parse()` or `parse_string()`.

(Which is why I originally wanted to add it to the library as `Gdk.RGBA.new_from_string()`.)

target_title: Adding a signal to a class from a subclass adds it also to the class parent

note.body:
For anyone needing it this is the solution thanks to Benjamin:

```
import gi
gi.require_version('Gtk', '4.0')
from gi.repository import GObject, Gtk


class Interface:    
    def __init_subclass__(cls, **kwargs):
        cls.signal_one = GObject.Signal('signal-one')
        cls.value = GObject.Property(type=int, default=1)
        super().__init_subclass__(**kwargs)

class SomeClass(Gtk.Label, Interface):
    __gtype_name__ = 'SomeClass'

class SomeOtherClass(Gtk.Label, Interface):
    __gtype_name__ = 'SomeOtherClass'
```

If you need pass arguments do `GObject.Signal('signal-one', arg_types=([int])`

target_title: Passing callbacks to Gtk.Builder never releases them

note.body:
Forgot to write in the end, pygobject sinks it in `pygi_arg_gclosure_from_py_marshal`. It is special casing the template case, so it could "just" not sink it to break the documented contract of `gtk_builder_create_closure` in the same way that GTK does. And, it would break if GTK is fixed.

This really needs a decision on the GTK side on how to move forward before doing anything.

target_title: Passing callbacks to Gtk.Builder never releases them

note.body:
Should probably add the summary here. GTK bug.

* `gtk_builder_create_closure` says that it returns a reference (didn't check the `create_closure` tagging, but I assume it is the same default value)
* `g_closure_new*` does *not* return a reference (i.e. it is created floating)
* `gtk_builder_cscope_create_closure_for_funcptr` does *not* create a reference. This is against the documentation.
* `gtk_builder_connect_signals` simply calls `g_signal_connect_closure_by_id`. Will add a ref and sink it.

So, assume a reference should be returned we need to change GTK, so that:
1. `gtk_builder_connect_signals` unrefs the closure after calling `g_signal_connect_closure_by_id`
2. `gtk_builder_cscope_create_closure_for_funcptr` adds a reference and sinks the closure immediately after creating it.

Workaround floating object test failures in minimal-meson build

note.body:
Well, that behaviour is kind of scary. And, it looks like it is an ancient workaround for an issue that should hopefully be gone, see `pygi_arg_object_to_py_called_from_c`

```
    /* HACK:
     * The following hack is to work around GTK sending signals which
     * contain floating widgets in them. This assumes control of how
     * references are added by the PyGObject wrapper and avoids the sink
     * behavior by explicitly passing GI_TRANSFER_EVERYTHING as the transfer
     * mode and then re-forcing the object as floating afterwards.
     *
     * See: https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=693400
     */
```

That said, if you want to go crazy, I think this works. Though, more fun thing with the weak ref disappearing on us and that causing a leak.
```
diff --git a/tests/test_object_marshaling.py b/tests/test_object_marshaling.py
index d52ff54f..de95659f 100644
--- a/tests/test_object_marshaling.py
+++ b/tests/test_object_marshaling.py
@@ -275,19 +275,29 @@ class TestVFuncsWithFloatingArg(unittest.TestCase):
 
     def test_vfunc_in_object_transfer_none_with_floating(self):
         vfuncs = self.VFuncs()
+        def ref(obj):
+            obj._ref()
+            return weakref.ref(obj)
+        vfuncs.ObjectRef = ref
+
         ref_count, is_floating = vfuncs.get_ref_info_for_vfunc_in_object_transfer_none(self.VFuncs.Object)
 
         gc.collect()
 
         # python wrapper should maintain the object as floating and add an additional ref
-        self.assertEqual(vfuncs.in_object_grefcount, 2)
+        self.assertEqual(vfuncs.in_object_grefcount, 3)
         self.assertTrue(vfuncs.in_object_is_floating)
 
         # vfunc caller should only have a single floating ref after the vfunc finishes
+        # (plus the one we added explicitly)
         if hasattr(sys, "getrefcount"):
-            self.assertEqual(ref_count, 1)
+            self.assertEqual(ref_count, 2)
         self.assertTrue(is_floating)
 
+        # BUG: There still is an extra reference to the C object. However, the
+        # python wrapper has already been killed, so we are leaking the object
+        # here.
+
         gc.collect()
         gc.collect()
         self.assertTrue(vfuncs.object_ref() is None)
@@ -536,6 +546,13 @@ class TestVFuncsWithHeldFloatingArg(unittest.TestCase):
         # Current ref count after C cleans up its reference
         self.assertEqual(vfuncs.object_ref().__grefcount__, 1)
 
+        # Our reference is still floating at this point ...
+        self.assertTrue(vfuncs.object_ref().is_floating())
+        # ... usually it should have been sunk within C at some point,
+        # do it here to avoid a critical warning.
+        vfuncs.object_ref()._ref_sink()
+        # However, that means that the above comment of "sinks and owns" is wrong.
+
         held_object_ref = weakref.ref(vfuncs.object_ref())
         del vfuncs.object_ref
         gc.collect()
```

target_title: Support free-threaded Python (3.13)

note.body:
> Apart from the caches there's not much to worry about? The only thing that can be tricky is loading libraries through girepository. We have fairly limited global state, which is initialized in the module's init methods - those are protected by python.

Oh, didn't know that module loading was protected already, that is useful.

Honestly, I did not take a closer look. But I am also not really expecting anything else. :smile:

Note that for the caching we probably wouldn't even need a full lock. An atomic assignment to `self->cache` and just immediately releasing the work again–if someone else filled it in already–is probably easier than actually locking everything.

Well, I am assuming that the GIR API is mostly read-only and threadsafe to begin with.

target_title: Support free-threaded Python (3.13)

note.body:
> I would say the sticky point are the internal caches that pygobject has for the classes.

Apart from the caches there's not much to worry about? The only thing that can be tricky is loading libraries through girepository. We have fairly limited global state, which is initialized in the module's init methods - those are protected by python.

> Beyond that, GLib/Gtk is generally not thread safe anyway and it is the user's job to ensure proper use.

Yup. But that's already the case, since we allow threading during the ffi calls.

The downside of not supporting free-threading is that the interpreter will default to GIL-mode as soon as it loads a module that does not support free-threading. It will be nice if PyGobject is not _that_ library :smiley: .

target_title: Use newer CPython constructs
Support free-threaded Python (3.13)

note.body:
I would say the sticky point are the internal caches that pygobject has for the classes. Look at e.g. `_wrap_g_callable_info_invoke` instantiating `self->cache` and storing it at the end of the function. It is unlikely, but this could race and is currently protected by the GIL (which will be dropped later when invoking the function in `pygi_invoke_c_callable`). I *think* that two threads calling the same function for the first time on two separate instances of the same base class could run into this kind of race.

Though, in this case, all that would happen is probably a small memory leak … which is pretty harmless overall

Beyond that, GLib/Gtk is generally not thread safe anyway and it is the user's job to ensure proper use.
